title: What is a Process Flow Diagram (PFD)? — Everything You Need to Know
excerpt: Learn what a Process Flow Diagram (PFD) is, why it matters in engineering, and how DrawnDimension delivers world-class PFD drafting services globally.
content:
In the world of chemical, oil & gas, and industrial engineering, a Process Flow Diagram (PFD) is the backbone of any project. Whether you're designing a new facility or upgrading an existing plant, a well-crafted PFD can mean the difference between a project completed on time and one riddled with costly errors.

At DrawnDimension, we specialize in delivering high-precision PFD services to clients worldwide. In this post, we break down everything you need to know about PFDs — and why accurate drafting matters more than ever.

What is a Process Flow Diagram (PFD)?

A Process Flow Diagram, commonly abbreviated as PFD, is a graphical representation of the major process equipment, flow streams, and key operating conditions within an industrial system. Unlike detailed engineering drawings, PFDs focus on the big picture: how materials and energy move through a system.

PFDs are used across industries including:

  • Oil & Gas processing plants
  • Chemical manufacturing facilities
  • Pharmaceutical production lines
  • Food & beverage processing
  • Power generation systems
  • Water treatment plants

Key Components of a PFD

1. Process Equipment

All major vessels, reactors, heat exchangers, pumps, compressors, and columns are shown with standard symbols.

2. Process Streams

Lines with directional arrows indicate the flow of materials, showing how inputs move through the process to outputs.

3. Operating Conditions

Key data such as temperature, pressure, and flow rates are annotated on the diagram.

4. Stream Tables

A data table summarizing stream compositions, flow rates, temperatures, and pressures is often included alongside the diagram.

5. Energy Balances

Heat inputs and outputs are shown to support energy optimization studies.

Why PFDs Are Critical in Engineering Projects

A PFD serves as the foundation document for all subsequent engineering work. Here is why they are indispensable:

  • Conceptual Design — Helps stakeholders visualize how the process works before detailed engineering begins.
  • Feasibility Studies — Supports technical and economic evaluation of a project.
  • HAZOP Preparation — Acts as the primary reference document for Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) studies.
  • Client Communication — Bridges the gap between engineers, operators, and management.
  • Regulatory Compliance — Required by regulatory agencies and insurance bodies in many industries.
  • Cost Estimation — Basis for generating bills of materials and project cost estimates.

PFD vs. P&ID: What is the Difference?

A common question engineers ask is: what is the difference between a PFD and a P&ID?

A PFD shows the overall process flow at a high level — major equipment and key streams. A Piping and Instrumentation Diagram (P&ID), on the other hand, goes deeper, showing every pipe, valve, instrument, and control loop in detail.

Think of the PFD as the roadmap and the P&ID as the street-level navigation. Both are essential — and DrawnDimension delivers both with equal precision.

Industry Standards for PFD Drafting

Professional PFDs are drafted in accordance with internationally recognized standards:

  • ISO 10628: Flow Diagrams for Process Plants
  • ANSI/ISA-5.1: Instrumentation Symbols and Identification
  • BS 5070: Engineering Diagram Drawing Practice

At DrawnDimension, all our PFDs are produced using AutoCAD and comply with these global standards, ensuring they are accepted by clients, contractors, and regulators worldwide.

Our PFD drafting service covers the full scope of process flow documentation:

  • Greenfield PFD development from process descriptions or block flow diagrams
  • PFD revision and updating for existing facilities
  • Conversion of hand-drawn sketches to professional CAD drawings
  • PFD review and redlining
  • Stream table preparation and data integration
  • Compliance checking against ISO and ANSI standards

We serve clients across the USA, UK, Canada, Australia, Middle East, Europe, and Southeast Asia. No project is too large or too small.

title: P&ID Drawings Explained: The Complete Guide to Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams
excerpt: Discover what P&ID drawings are, their symbols, standards, and why accurate P&ID drafting is critical for safe plant operations. DrawnDimension provides professional P&ID services globally.
content:
In any industrial or process engineering project, few documents are as critical — or as complex — as the Piping and Instrumentation Diagram (P&ID). Often called the 'bible' of a process plant, P&IDs govern everything from construction and operations to maintenance and safety.

DrawnDimension provides expert P&ID drafting and revision services to engineering firms, EPCs, and industrial companies worldwide. Whether you need new P&IDs from scratch or revisions to existing drawings, our team delivers with precision, speed, and full compliance with international standards.

What is a P&ID (Piping and Instrumentation Diagram)?

A Piping and Instrumentation Diagram (P&ID) is a detailed, schematic drawing that shows all the piping, process equipment, instrumentation, control systems, safety devices, and interlocks within a process facility. It is a critical engineering document used throughout the entire lifecycle of an industrial plant — from design and construction through operations, maintenance, and decommissioning.

What Does a P&ID Include?

  • All process piping including pipe sizes, specifications, and insulation requirements
  • All process equipment: vessels, heat exchangers, pumps, compressors, filters, reactors
  • All instrumentation: flow meters, temperature sensors, pressure transmitters, analyzers
  • Control loops and automatic control systems
  • Safety systems: relief valves, rupture disks, safety shutdown systems
  • Utility systems: steam, cooling water, nitrogen, compressed air, electrical heat tracing
  • Equipment and instrument tag numbers
  • Valve types and specifications

P&ID Symbols and Standards

P&IDs use standardized symbols to represent equipment and instruments. The most widely used standards include:

  • ISA 5.1 (ANSI/ISA-5.1-2009): The primary global standard for instrumentation symbols
  • ISO 10628-2: Chemical and petrochemical plants — flow diagram symbols
  • IEC 62424: Representation of process control engineering

At DrawnDimension, we apply the correct symbol library and standard based on your project location and client requirements.

P&ID vs. PFD: Key Differences

While both are flow diagrams, they serve very different purposes:

  • A Process Flow Diagram (PFD) shows the overall process at a high level — major equipment, key streams, and operating conditions. It is used in concept design and HAZOP preparation.
  • A P&ID shows every single pipe, instrument, valve, and control element. It is used for detailed engineering, construction, commissioning, and operations.

The P&ID is significantly more detailed and is the primary reference document for all plant personnel.

Why Are P&IDs So Important?

Safety and Regulatory Compliance

P&IDs are a legal and regulatory requirement in most industries. They form the basis of Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) studies, HAZOP reviews, and safety case documentation. Regulatory agencies such as OSHA (USA), HSE (UK), and similar bodies require accurate and up-to-date P&IDs.

Construction and Commissioning

During construction, P&IDs guide pipe fabricators, instrument engineers, and contractors. An error in a P&ID can lead to costly rework, construction delays, and safety risks.

Operations and Maintenance

Operations teams rely on P&IDs to understand how the plant works. Maintenance technicians use them to safely isolate equipment for repair.

Management of Change (MOC)

When modifications are made to a plant, P&IDs must be updated to reflect as-built conditions. Out-of-date P&IDs are a major safety hazard.

  • New P&ID development from PFDs, process descriptions, or conceptual sketches
  • P&ID review and redmarking
  • As-built P&ID updates
  • P&ID conversion from hand drawings or legacy software to AutoCAD
  • Smart P&ID development (using Aveva PDMS, AVEVA E3D, or similar platforms on request)
  • Compliance review against ISA, ISO, and client standards

We have experience across oil & gas, chemical, pharmaceutical, water treatment, food processing, and power generation sectors.

Our Process: How We Deliver Your P&IDs

  • Step 2: Our engineers review the scope and confirm deliverables, standards, and timeline

title: HAZOP Study: What It Is, Why It Matters, and How DrawnDimension Can Help
excerpt: Understand what a HAZOP study is, how it is conducted, and why it is essential for process plant safety. DrawnDimension provides professional HAZOP facilitation and documentation globally.
content:
Process safety is not just a regulatory requirement — it is a moral and business imperative. A single process safety incident can result in fatalities, catastrophic equipment damage, environmental harm, and regulatory shutdown. The HAZOP study is one of the most powerful tools in the process safety toolkit, and it has prevented countless disasters across the oil & gas, chemical, pharmaceutical, and power industries.

DrawnDimension provides expert HAZOP facilitation, documentation, and follow-up services to engineering companies and industrial operators worldwide.

What is a HAZOP Study?

A Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP) is a structured, systematic technique used to identify potential hazards and operability problems in a process design or existing plant. It is performed by a multidisciplinary team of engineers, using a series of guidewords (such as MORE, LESS, NO, REVERSE, AS WELL AS) applied to process parameters (flow, temperature, pressure, composition) to challenge the design and identify deviations that could lead to hazardous situations.

HAZOP is an internationally recognized methodology governed by:

  • IEC 61882: Hazard and Operability Studies (HAZOP Studies) — Application Guide
  • ISO 31000: Risk Management Guidelines
  • OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard 29 CFR 1910.119
  • UK COMAH Regulations (Control of Major Accident Hazards)

When Should a HAZOP Be Conducted?

  • During the detailed engineering phase of a new process facility (when P&IDs are at approximately 30-60% completion)
  • Before commissioning and startup of a new plant
  • When a process modification is proposed (as part of the Management of Change process)
  • Periodically for existing operating plants (revalidation HAZOP)
  • When a major process upset or near-miss incident has occurred

The HAZOP Process: Step by Step

Step 1: Define Scope and Objectives

The HAZOP leader defines which systems and P&IDs will be studied, the study objectives, and the required team composition.

Step 2: Assemble the Team

A HAZOP team typically includes a Process Engineer, Instrument/Control Engineer, Operations Representative, Safety Engineer, and a skilled HAZOP Chairman/Facilitator.

Step 3: Collect and Review Documentation

The team reviews the P&IDs, PFDs, equipment data sheets, process descriptions, and operating procedures.

Step 4: HAZOP Sessions

The team works node by node through the P&IDs, applying guidewords to process parameters:

  • Guidewords: NO/NONE, MORE, LESS, AS WELL AS, PART OF, REVERSE, OTHER THAN, EARLY, LATE, BEFORE, AFTER
  • Parameters: Flow, Temperature, Pressure, Level, Composition, Phase, Reaction, Utility
  • For each deviation: identify causes, consequences, existing safeguards, and recommended actions

Step 5: HAZOP Report and Action Register

All findings, recommendations, and action items are documented in a formal HAZOP report. Each recommendation is assigned an action owner and target completion date.

Step 6: Close-Out

Actions are implemented and closed out. Significant actions may trigger a HAZOP revalidation.

HAZOP Guidewords and Their Meaning

  • NO / NONE: No flow, no transfer — what happens if there is zero flow?
  • MORE: Higher than intended — high flow, high temperature, high pressure
  • LESS: Lower than intended — low flow, low temperature, low pressure
  • AS WELL AS: An additional component or phase is present
  • PART OF: Only part of the intended transfer occurs
  • REVERSE: Reverse flow, back-flow
  • OTHER THAN: Something completely different happens — wrong material, wrong destination

DrawnDimension HAZOP Services

Our process safety specialists provide:

  • HAZOP facilitation for new projects, modifications, and revalidations
  • HAZOP documentation — professional, structured reports in Microsoft Word or client templates
  • Action register preparation and tracking
  • Risk matrix development and consequence classification
  • Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) following HAZOP
  • What-If Analysis (WIA) as a complementary or alternative technique
  • Process safety support throughout the project lifecycle

Why HAZOP Documentation Quality Matters

The quality of HAZOP documentation is as important as the study itself. Poorly documented HAZOPs create legal liability, fail regulatory audits, and leave action items unresolved. DrawnDimension produces clear, structured, and audit-ready HAZOP reports that meet the requirements of regulatory authorities worldwide.

FAQs: HAZOP Study Services

This depends on the complexity and number of P&IDs. A small process unit may take 2-3 days of sessions. A large, complex facility may take 2-4 weeks.

Do you work to international standards?

Yes. We apply IEC 61882, and we are familiar with industry standards from BP, Shell, ExxonMobil, Saudi Aramco, and other major operators.

title: Technical Drawing Services: The Foundation of Every Successful Engineering Project
excerpt: DrawnDimension provides professional technical drawing services for engineering, manufacturing, and construction globally. ISO-compliant, precise, and delivered on time.
content:
Technical drawings are the universal language of engineering. From a simple machined bracket to a complex offshore platform, every manufactured object and built structure begins with a technical drawing. The quality, accuracy, and clarity of those drawings directly determine the quality and accuracy of what gets built.

DrawnDimension provides comprehensive technical drawing services to manufacturers, engineering firms, construction companies, and product developers worldwide.

What is a Technical Drawing?

A technical drawing is a detailed, standardized graphical representation of an object, system, or structure that communicates precise dimensions, tolerances, materials, finishes, and construction requirements to the people who will build, assemble, or install it. Unlike artistic drawings, technical drawings follow strict international standards to ensure they are interpreted consistently and correctly by anyone, anywhere in the world.

Types of Technical Drawings We Produce

General Arrangement (GA) Drawings

GA drawings show the overall layout and arrangement of an assembly, plant, or structure — including overall dimensions, major component locations, and access and maintenance clearances.

Detail Drawings

Fully dimensioned drawings of individual parts, including all dimensions, tolerances, surface finishes, material specifications, and notes required for manufacturing.

Assembly Drawings

Show how individual components fit together into a complete assembly, including part numbers, bill of materials, and assembly notes.

Fabrication Drawings

Used by fabricators and welders to build structural steel, pressure vessels, pipe spools, and other fabricated assemblies. Include weld symbols, material grades, and NDT requirements.

Isometric Drawings

3D isometric views that provide a clear visual representation of piping systems, structural assemblies, or equipment arrangements.

Piping Isometrics

Detailed isometric drawings of individual pipe runs, showing all dimensions, fittings, welds, supports, and materials. Essential for pipe fabrication and installation.

Schematic Diagrams

Simplified diagrams showing the functional arrangement of systems — hydraulic schematics, pneumatic schematics, electrical schematics, and process schematics.

Installation Drawings

Show how equipment and components should be installed on site, including fixing details, dimensions, and interfacing information.

International Standards for Technical Drawings

Professional technical drawings are produced in accordance with international standards. Compliance with these standards ensures drawings are universally understood:

  • ISO 128: Technical drawings — General principles of presentation
  • ISO 286: Limits and fits — Basis of tolerances and deviations
  • ISO 1101: Geometrical tolerancing — GD&T
  • ASME Y14.5: Dimensioning and Tolerancing (US standard)
  • BS 8888: Technical product documentation (UK standard)
  • ISO 10628: Flow diagrams for process plants

At DrawnDimension, we apply the correct standard for your project location, industry, and client requirements — whether that is ISO, ASME, BS, or a company-specific standard.

GD&T: Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing

Modern technical drawings use Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing (GD&T) to precisely define the allowable variation in manufactured parts. GD&T symbols specify tolerances for form, orientation, location, and runout, allowing manufacturers to produce parts that fit and function as designed — even across different suppliers and countries.

Our drafters are proficient in both ASME Y14.5 and ISO 1101 GD&T standards and can apply them to your drawings as required.
